title: ASX set to rise amid positive earnings, more Brexit optimism
text:

Today's agenda

Local: WBC leading index September; NZ CPI Q3

Overseas data: Euro zone trade balance August; UK CPI September; US retail sales September, NAHB housing market index October, business inventories August and US Federal Reserve Beige Book.

From today's Financial Review

IMF slashes growth as PM rejects stimulus call: The IMF has slashed Australia's economic growth forecast to just 1.7 per cent and advised world governments to unleash a spending stimulus.

Home loan inquiry won't find anything new: The problems in the mortgage market are well known and the latest ACCC inquiry make any new discoveries, says the Productivity Commission's Stephen King.

In a mixed-up market, growth is still a focus: There's a fascinating juxtaposition between capital raisings by Latitude Financial and RFG. But in a fickle market, a Citi veteran says growth is a focus.

United States

Stocks were broadly higher on Wall Street as investors applauded some good results in the first batch of earnings reports from major US companies.

UnitedHealth Group, the nation's largest insurer, jumped 7.4 per centafter again raising its 2019 earnings forecast. JPMorgan Chase rose 4.1 per cent after reporting results that easily beat analysts' forecasts, thanks partly to higher interest rates and solid gains in investment banking.

Goldman Sachs was stung by slumping investments in some big names in the third quarter, taking a $US267 million ($395 million) hit in the period on public equity investments such as ride-hailing company Uber, Avantor and Tradeweb Markets.

Advertisement

Bank of America shares rallied after news that Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway is seeking permission from the Federal Reserve to potentially increase its stake in the company to more than 10 per cent, a level that often triggers a regulatory review.

Europe

European stocks rose to their highest in nearly three months, with Irish stocks soaring almost 3 per cent.

Optimism over a Brexit breakthrough turned the benchmark FTSE 100 stock index in London, which usually suffers from the pound's sharp rise, positive. The pan European STOXX 600 index jumped 1.1 per cent, with other major regional indices including Germany's DAX and France's CAC 40 gaining a similar amount.

British banks Lloyds, Royal Bank of Scotland and Barclays, considered some of the most vulnerable to the UK economy and Brexit uncertainty, rose between 4 per cent and 5 per cent.

Asia

Hong Kong stocks slipped amid worries over China's economic health and uncertainties around Sino-US trade talks, but losses were limited as the city's central bank cut banks' capital buffer to support the economy. The Hang Seng index fell 0.1 per cent. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority has cut the amount of cash that banks must keep as reserves, releasing an extra $US25.50 to $US38.24 billion into the broader economy.

Chinese stocks snapped a five-day winning streak after the latest factory gate data added to China's economic woes and the end of the trade war remained elusive.

Advertisement

Around the region, MSCI's Asia ex-Japan stock index was firmer by 0.04 per cent while Japan's Nikkei index closed up 1.87 per cent.

Currencies

The British pound surged on optimism regarding a Brexit deal, climbing 1.5 per cent on the day to $US1.28. It also rose by the same margin against the euro and was last trading 1.4% higher at 86.29 pence.

The dollar traded mixed. The dollar index fell 0.16 per cent, while the euro was up 0.07 per cent at $US1.1036.

The yen weakened 0.35 per cent versus the greenback to 108.80 per dollar. Sterling rose to $US1.273, up 0.98 per cent on the day.

Euro zone government bonds sold off after a news report that UK and EU negotiators were close to a draft deal on Brexit boosted investors' risk appetite.

German 10-year government bond yields rose to 2.5 month highs, up as much as 5 basis points on the day, with a sharp sell-off taking place following news of the potential draft deal.

Money markets scaled back expectations of a rate cut, to as low as a 10 per cent chance of a 10 bps rate cut from the European Central Bank in December, down from a 20 bps probability on Friday.

Advertisement

Commodities

Gold fell as growing risk appetite boosted investor demand for equities and the dollar also strengthened, while a sustained supply crunch in palladium propelled the price of that precious metal to a record high.

"Right now what's pushing it [gold] down is the stocks, we have earnings coming out now and stocks look strong, there is no risk aversion right now, the dollar is going higher," said Bob Haberkorn, senior market strategist at RJO Futures.

Palladium continued its strong rally, up 1.1 per cent to $US1,734.36 an ounce, after hitting a record US$1,739.93. It has rallied more than $US300 since early August

"Palladium is in short supply, it will continue to be so and higher prices maybe till $2,000 is well within the realm of possibilities, particularly if we see automotive activity rebound a bit," said Bart Melek, head of commodity strategies at TD Securities in Toronto.

Oil futures were slightly lower. Brent crude fell 17 US cents to $US59.28 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude dropped 13 US cents to $US53.46 a barrel.

Nickel prices rebounded after heavy losses at the beginning of the week that fuelled an $825 tumble for nickel in less than five minutes on Monday. It pared some of those losses on Tuesday, rising 2.4 per cent in final open-outcry trading to $US16,995 a tonne.

Australian sharemarket

Advertisement

Australian shares were unable to capitalise on their positive start to the week, as a series of weak guidance statements from retailers and media companies conspired to keep the stock market flat on Tuesday.

Global developments, such as the retreat of optimism around the US-China trade deal, also weighed on the market.

The trading session saw the benchmark S &P/ASX 200 Index add 9.4 points, or 0.1 per cent, to 6652 points. The All Ordinaries Index advanced 5.4 points, or 0.1 per cent, to 6763.3 points.

The result owed much to the performance of Southern Cross Media, in particular, where shares took an 18.6 per cent battering to finish the session at 94¢.

description: Australian shares are set to lift as markets rallied on positive earnings reports on Wall Street and further optimism over Brexit.
